reviews.review_msg: great lectures
pragmatic
egalatarian
at simon fraser the mountain air is crisp
pertinent
at times things appeared to be addleminded
pulchritudinous
beware of surprises
valuable
obtuse
its an english class not a rock concert
tough
groovy
She doesnt seem to care much about students .

Be an English teacher yet keep misusing the word "literally" just bcuz she thinks she sounds cool when saying it. Hilarious !!!! Plus her attitude toward students is unacceptable too!Never smile once!!!
great teacher

I found the lectures pretty boring, however you can tell she's very passionate about photography.  I felt it had little to do with what we were reading and just an add on. The final essay was incredibly hard to understand in terms of what she wanted. I didn't find her helpful, however she seemed to care, a little? The topic itself was interesting.
Tough course (lots of reading, fair marker) but professor made it manageable.

It was an okay course. Focused on the Harlem Renaissance, its literature, and a surprising amount on photography. Quite a lot of reading, about as many assignments as a 400-level course, and a final to boot. Lectures were sort of dry because it was just going through slides relating to the texts and a lot of the essays on photography were tedious.

Absolutely outstanding prof. I ended up having him for 5 classes, and to be honest, I wish I could have taken more with him. These comments are all bang-on. He will never make you feel wrong if you raise your hand with an answer. Caring prof, wants to help you. Go to his office hours and pick his brain for your essays & you'll get excellent marks.

Nilsson seems like a nice guy, but his classes are kind of a joke. The reason he gets high ratings is because he gives easy grades. Take his classes to raise your GPA, but don't expect to get anything out of them you can't get with a membership to Blockbuster -- just shows movies all day and has students give presentations.
Super nice guy, but he pitches a lot of slow balls. The material is way too simplistic for an upper division course.
Absolutely one of the best new teachers at SFU.  Fun, interesting and endlessly encouraging.  Make class loose and fun, and encourages great discussion.  A must-take!
Stay away from this new age instructor

Nadine is by far one of the best instructors I've encountered in my university experience.  She was not only informative and engaging, but also fun and easy to get along with.  Anyone interested in an English class that will goes beyond typical literary theories will love her teaching style.
Nadine is a great lecturer and is very passionate about the course material. She allows for creativity in her assignment and celebrates innovative ideas. I thoroughly enjoyed her class. A great prof.

I think Christine is a great prof even though the seminars are tedious and repetitive at times. I think she's a great prof and when she cut you or someone off in class was because it was probably a bad comment/**** comment. I think she brings a fresh approach to teaching English even when the books are a snooze and offbeat at times.

He is honestly not a great prof and he will brag about it! He marks based off of what he thinks is right, not if the paper is actually well written. His feedback is not great, his lectures are go with the flow (even though there is an exam), and his grading criteria is MIA. He also just will not teach you anything so do not expect to learn.

Knows the material but his presentation leaves a lot to be desired. Unprepared for class, lectures all over the place, constantly losing the thread or forgetting what he had taught us, lackadaisical attitude towards lecturing, unrealistic grading expectations. Kind of a narcissist; invited a guest lecturer twice and then talked over her. Tiresome.
A bit sporadic and tends to digress, but all in all a he knows his stuff and does his best

Great Prof. Only class I actually looked forward to in the mornings. Great group discussion and I really enjoyed Jon's upbeat, occasionally sarcastic personality. Not an easy prof but definitely rewards effort. I 100% recommend him!

Jon Smith managed to make political rhetoric fun and engaging and I loved going to this class. He also made sure to prepare us for the final exam to an extent I've rarely seen in 300-level courses, which I appreciated. I would highly recommend both the course and the professor.
Is Jon Smith a hero? Yes.
I look forward to every class with this man. He completes me, and I him.

It's only a few weeks into term, and people are already complaining about Dr. Smith's lack of organization. Frankly, I love that he's not one of those Professors who comes to class with the same slides and notes that he's been using for ten years, and will keep using until he retires. Smith's spontaneous style is what makes this class so much fun.

Stephen Collis is the poet of my dreams. He's hilarious, handsome, kind, and passionate about poetry, especially concerning women writers. His passions really do present themselves in his lectures. You'll find that the readings are actually fun to read and discuss. I never skipped a class!
Did an entire unit on Bob Dylan Protest songs- how cool is that?  Every class was very interesting.  Great reading list, not mainstream stuff.  He has sexy hands too, as strange as that sounds.
No Comments
Cool guy - not an easy grade.
Great prof, but a difficult marker. Very specific in what he looks for in papers.
Steve is a great prof.
